message_1: A factory produces electronic bulbs with a mean life of 800 hours and a standard deviation of 60 hours. A sample of 100 bulbs is selected. Find the 95% confidence interval for the mean life of the bulbs in the sample.
message_2:
To find the 95% confidence interval for the mean life of the bulbs in the sample, we will use the formula:

Confidence interval = x̄ ± (Z * (σ / √n))

where x̄ is the sample mean, Z is the Z-score corresponding to the desired confidence level (95% in this case), σ is the population standard deviation, and n is the sample size.

In this problem, we have:
x̄ = 800 hours (mean life of the bulbs)
σ = 60 hours (standard deviation)
n = 100 (sample size)

For a 95% confidence interval, the Z-score is 1.96 (you can find this value in a standard Z-score table).

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

Confidence interval = 800 ± (1.96 * (60 / √100))

Confidence interval = 800 ± (1.96 * (60 / 10))

Confidence interval = 800 ± (1.96 * 6)

Confidence interval = 800 ± 11.76

So, the 95% confidence interval for the mean life of the bulbs in the sample is (788.24, 811.76) hours.
